docs.snippet: Actually, most of the criticism has been from people who believe the film excuses the main character's culpability in allowing the incineration of 300 Jews. But the joint statement from the movie's director, Stephen Daldry, Mr. Weinstein, the prod...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the Oscar voting is closed, the people behind "The Reader," including Harvey Weinstein, are swinging back, quoting the head of the Anti-Defamation League and Elie Wiesel to link the film's detractors to Holocaust deniers. Actually, most of the criticism has been from people who believe the film excuses the main character's culpability in allowing the incineration of 300 Jews. But the joint statement from the movie's director, Stephen Daldry, Mr. Weinstein, the producer Donna Giglotti, and the screenwriter, David Hare, didn't go there:
docs.abstract: Actually, most of the criticism has been from people who believe the film excuses the main character's culpability in allowing the incineration of 300 Jews. But the joint statement from the movie's director, Stephen Daldry, Mr. Weinstein, the producer Donna Giglotti, and the screenwriter, David Hare, didn't go there.

headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: 'Reader' Riot Act

docs.snippet: The fashion world is uniformly swaying to the drumbeat of Africa, and so are we. In the new Women's Spring 2009 issue of T, we spotlight Josephine Baker, a perennial muse who is once again shorthand for Africanesque glamour, having inspired the in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The fashion world is uniformly swaying to the drumbeat of Africa, and so are we. In the new Women's Spring 2009 issue of T, we spotlight Josephine Baker, a perennial muse who is once again shorthand for Africanesque glamour, having inspired the influential Louis Vuitton show; Camilla Akrans photographs, and Suzy Menkes writes about, the many African motifs dominating the runways; and we meet El Anatsui, the Nigerian sculptor who has emerged as an art-world name to watch and to drop. Elsewhere in the issue, we look at people who are generating as much cultural traction as the mother continent, including the stylist and editor du jour Katie Grand, the designers Oscar de la Renta and Giambattista Valli, and our cover star, Rosario Dawson. What are you waiting for? Take a walk on the wildlife side.
docs.abstract: The fashion world is uniformly swaying to the drumbeat of Africa, and so are we. In the new Women's Spring 2009 issue of T, we spotlight Josephine Baker, a perennial muse who is once again shorthand for Africanesque glamour, having inspired the influential Louis Vuitton show; Camilla Akrans photographs, and Suzy Menkes writes about, the many African motifs dominating the runways; and we meet El Anatsui, the Nigerian sculptor who has emerged as an art-world name to watch and to drop. Elsewhere in the issue, we look at people who are generating as much cultural traction as the mother continent, including the stylist and editor du jour Katie Grand, the designers Oscar de la Renta and Giambattista Valli, and our cover star, Rosario Dawson. What are you waiting for? Take a walk on the wildlife side.

headline.main: Now Online | T's Women's Fashion Issue

docs.snippet: Are the reviews getting pithier, or crankier? Tough call. Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is winding down, and the critics are crystal clear about what they don't like (uninspired merchiness, has-been-done-since-the-1970s looks) and what they do (focus...
docs.lead_paragraph: Are the reviews getting pithier, or crankier? Tough call. Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is winding down, and the critics are crystal clear about what they don't like (uninspired merchiness, has-been-done-since-the-1970s looks) and what they do (focused extravagance, hasn't-been-done-since-the-1870s looks) -- yet somehow they almost never agree. Zip through Scorecard's rapidfire recap of reviews of Anna Sui, Doo.Ri, Marchesa, Michael Kors, Oscar de la Renta, 3.1 Phillip Lim, Proenza Schouler, Richard Chai and Tory Burch, then cast your own vote.
docs.abstract: Are the reviews getting pithier, or crankier? Tough call. Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is winding down, and the critics are crystal clear about what they don't like (uninspired merchiness, has-been-done-since-the-1970s looks) and what they do (focused extravagance, hasn't-been-done-since-the-1870s looks) -- yet somehow they almost never agree. Zip through Scorecard's rapidfire recap of reviews of Anna Sui, Doo.Ri, Marchesa, Michael Kors, Oscar de la Renta, 3.1 Phillip Lim, Proenza Schouler, Richard Chai and Tory Burch, then cast your own vote.MarchesaDesigner: Georgina ChapmanDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 18, Chelsea Art Museum, 556 West 22nd StreetPhotos: slide show "Too much was never enough for concoctions of ribbons, bows, lace, ruching, frills and furbelows. The saving grace? The odd quirky touch, like embroidered unicorns, and a palette of black, white and smoky gray to calm the decorative excess." (The International Herald Tribune) "You expected Count Vronsky to enter" (The New York Times) "The 25 looks ably ran the gamut of what our millennial Cinderellas and Snow Whites (also known as A-listers) might clamor to wear" (style.com) "Brava to Georgina Chapman for her bold rejection of restraint, so exquisitely rendered" (WWD) 3.1 Phillip LimDesigner: Phillip LimDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 17, the Tent, Bryant ParkPhotos: slide show "Phillip Lim's rock 'n' roll hit a familiar spot: those swinging London 1960s and glam-rock 1970s when the dandified shirt (for both sexes) was a counterpart to skinny flared pants. Add Carnaby Street suits and Sergeant Pepper military coats." (The International Herald Tribune) " 'It's about fun,' said Lim. It's also about merch -- mountains of it. In need of an edit? Maybe so, but if business is good, then bring it on." (style.com) "the collection could have benefited from a less stylized hand" (WWD) Anna SuiDesigner: Anna SuiDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 18, the Tent, Bryant ParkPhotos: slide show "With 'Gossip Girl' stars sitting front row, Anna Sui produced a fresh take on her Gothic girls: flowery, frilly, dolly dresses in dusky colors" (The International Herald Tribune) "Way to kick it, Anna" (style.com) "showed Sui can craft snappy contemporary pieces that don't scrimp on detail. Merci, madame." (WWD) Doo.RiDesigner: Doo-Ri ChungDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 18, Milk Gallery, 450 West 15th StreetPhotos: slide show "Doo Ri's favorite drapes and folds nested gracefully at the neck and gave soft volume to blouses that are a key item for next autumn's wardrobe" (The International Herald Tribune) "[Chung] really let it rip when it came to the details" (style.com) "this was a cooler, darker side of Doo.Ri" (WWD) Michael KorsDesigner: Michael KorsDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 18, the Tent, Bryant ParkPhotos: slide show "Tailoring, tailoring, tailoring: Could Michael Kors have said it any clearer Wednesday morning? His show was terrific." (The New York Times) "The show could have done with some unpredictable gestures like an insert of soft, sweet color and more of the designer's bold knits" (The International Herald Tribune) "Michael Kors knows how to take a theme and run with it. One season it's Ali MacGraw's 1970s; more recently it was 'Mad Men.' But for fall, it's not about a movie, or a TV show; it's about real life." (style.com) "Kors dug in his investment heels a bit too authoritatively, much like a frugal parent insisting the kids save three-quarters of their allowance. Smart, yes, far-sighted, for sure -- and in this case, plenty chic -- just not much fun." (WWD)
